title: 108_hr5319
content: The Act titled "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property upon subsequent purchase of renewable energy property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property if the seller acquires renewable energy property within the replacement period. Gain will only result to the extent that the sale price exceeds the cost of the renewable energy property acquired. The nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property is allowed if renewable energy property is acquired within the replacement period. Gain is recognized only if the sale price exceeds the cost of the renewable energy property acquired. Renewable energy property refers to facilities in the US using renewable energy sources for electricity generation or fuel manufacturing. The tax code allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property if renewable energy property is acquired within the replacement period. An interest in a partnership is treated as an interest in the partnership's assets, stock in a corporation focused on renewable energy is treated as such property, and similar rules apply to cooperatives. The replacement period for real property sale is a 2-year period after the sale date. Taxpayer must identify property to be received within 180 days to qualify as like-kind property. Basis of renewable energy property is determined accordingly. The basis of renewable energy property is the same as the exchanged property, adjusted for any money received and gain or loss recognized. If a taxpayer disposes of renewable energy property, any unrecognized gain from the exchange will be recognized. The gain from the acquisition of renewable energy property is not recognized under certain circumstances, such as after the taxpayer's death or in cases of tax avoidance. There are limitations on when such gains must be recognized. The Secretary must be satisfied that the disposition of renewable energy property was not for the purpose of avoiding federal income tax. If a taxpayer realizes gain from selling renewable energy property and elects nonrecognition of gain, the statute of limitations for assessing any deficiency is extended to 3 years from the date the Secretary is notified of the taxpayer's cost of purchasing the property and intention not to purchase. The taxpayer's cost of purchasing renewable energy property may result in nonrecognition of gain. If the taxpayer fails to purchase renewable energy property within the replacement period, a deficiency may be assessed within 3 years. A conforming amendment to Section 1016(a) of the Code is made to address this issue. A conforming amendment is made to Section 1016(a) of the Code regarding the nonrecognition of gain on the acquisition of property under section 1046. Nonrecognition of gain from sale of real property upon subsequent purchase of renewable energy property applies to real property sold after December 31, 2004.
